Does every graph with $m$ edges contain a subgraph with $\gg m^{2/3}$ edges which contains no $C_4$?



Originally asked by Bollob\'{a}s and Erd\H{o}s in 'a colloquium on graph theory at Tihany' with $m^{2/3}$ replaced by $m^{3/4}$. Folkman showed this is false with the counterexample $K_{n,n^2}$, which has $n^3$ edges, and yet every subgraph with $>n^2+\binom{n}{2}$ edges contains a $C_4$.

In \cite{Er71} Erd\H{o}s revises the conjecture to $m^{2/3}$, and notes $\gg m^{1/2}$ is trivial. In a footnote he says Szemer\'{e}di proved this conjecture, but gives no reference, and I could not find such a result in the literature.

This problem was first solved in the affirmative by Conlon, Fox, and Sudakov \cite{CFS14b}. A simple proof is given by Hunter in the comments.




References


[CFS14b] D. Conlon, J. Fox, and B. Sudakov, Large subgraphs without complete bipartite graphs. arXiv:1401.6711 (2014).

[Er71] Erd\H{o}s, P., Some unsolved problems in graph theory and combinatorial analysis. Combinatorial Mathematics and its Applications (Proc.
Conf., Oxford, 1969) (1971), 97-109.
